Waipawa - Don 857 8347. ##Story Name## 15ultimo Some big names in cycling have started their cycling career at the annual Ultimo Cycling CHB two-day junior tour being held on March 26 and 27, and this year there are again some up-and-coming names among the competitors. The tour has been running for about eight years, and is the only one of its kind in the country featuring races in four grades - under-19, under-17, under-15 and under-13, for both boys and girls. The first race, the 3.2km prologue, starts at Pukeora Estate on Saturday morning and follows the old main road around the bottom of the hill, ending at the top of the hill. Cycling CHB member Tim Mackie says the kids love this course, which is another unique aspect of this tour with its hill-top finish. "It's different from the usual time trials which tend to be run on longer, flat roads - this has got a grunty hill finish which they enjoy." After the prologue, a number of road races will be held on Saturday in the vicinity of Hatuma Lime Company. In a change from previous years, the criterium on Sunday will be held in Otane, rather than starting at CHB College. Tim says this is a one kilometre circuit near the Otane village and again this particular part of the tour is unique in that it's open for both boys and girls at the same time. Pukeora Estate is the main accommodation venue for the tour that attracts competitors and their families from the north of Auckland to Wellington, and sometimes the South Island. "This is a fun, friendly event that is well organised," says Tim. "We are lucky that we have quiet country roads that are challenging enough for all age groups, and give them a taste of competitive cycling." Past winners who have gone on to achieve big things include Patrick Bevin (who is currently coming third in the Paris to Nice classic), Campbell Stewart (who won the under-19s last year and has since gone on and won two junior world champ track gold medals), Georgia Williams (who is now in the NZ track team) and of course CHB's own multi-international gold medal winner Regan Gough. Campbell will be back to contest his title this year, likely battling it out with another frontrunner, Robert Stannard, who won this year's Cycling CHB Tour de Beautiful. Some of the local riders to watch out for this year include Jack Curruthers (under-19 boys), Thomas Higgins (under-17 boys), Hana Peacock (under-15 girls, last year's under-13 girls winner), and Laura Bickers (under-17 girls). Organisers thanked all the sponsors of the event, including Pukeora Estate and Hatuma Lime Company, the Cycling CHB volunteers who drive vehicles and perform marshall duties, and the volunteers who helped prepare the road beneath Pukeora Hill. ##Story Name## 15stewart This week is Brain Injury Awareness week, and for the last 10 years the Stewart Centre @ EIT has been providing rehabilitation for people with brain injuries in Central Hawke's Bay. In a new initiative the Centre is starting a group programme in Waipukurau. Working with the Paul Hunter Centre in Waipukurau, the Stewart Centre @ EIT will be meeting on land that is presently not being used behind Paul Hunter Centre. The Centre will initially establish gardens and other activities. The group will be run three afternoons a week and clients will work with a rehabilitation coach on activities that are enjoyable and encourage independence, such as gardening, wood and stone carving, swimming, gym programmes and computer courses. Stewart Centre @ EIT supported living services co-ordinator Kerry Harper says the activities arose from a philosophy that it is best for people with brain injuries and those who have had strokes to be integrated in the community and be as independent as possible. ACC and the Ministry of Health also promote this. Living skills coaches work with people in their homes and in the community one-to-one. Their role is to scaffold supports around a client, says Kerry. "Living skills coaches are not caregivers. The clients are doing the work; our role is to prompt and encourage. We call it 'cuing not doing'." Like the clients, coaches come from all walks of life and their work is about keeping it real for clients, enabling them to live at home and supporting them to be part of the community and responsible for themselves. Self responsibility is encouraged. While having a brain injury is traumatic, people still need to be socially responsible. Coaches assist clients in managing their home, which may involve supporting with housework, getting children to school and clients to therapy or to Stewart Centre @ EIT programmes. Kerry also provides input to the National Certificate in Health Disability and Aged Support - Level 3 with EIT tutors in Waipukurau. The Stewart Centre @ EIT has 96 clients throughout Hawke's Bay and their main service operates from their facility on the EIT campus in Taradale. Forty clients are receiving supported living services provided by 20 coaches who are matched to the clients they work with. The Stewart Centre @ EIT provides a weekly programme of activities that are meaningful and purposeful including communication and education courses, men's and women's groups, woodwork, cooking sports and gym programmes. The overall aim is to provide a safe environment where clients can improve skills in communication, build self confidence, improve problem solving and planning skills, learn to set goals and learn teamwork. The EIT campus allows clients to get involved in a diverse environment. ? In New Zealand, about 90 people sustain a brain injury every day and the impact can be significant. A traumatic head injury may be the result of a car accident, sports injury, assault, fall or knock to the head. Injuries can also result from strokes, heart attacks, meningitis, infections or poisoning from drugs, alcohol, gases, solvents or pesticides. ##Story Name## ttrisk In the current environment, farmers are frequently exposed to the vagaries of weather, prices and disease. They often live on the edge of extreme uncertainty about, for instance, whether rainfall will be good over the season or what prices they will receive for produce sold. These risks are not under the control of farmers, so developing a way to cope and manage them is a good business strategy. A recent survey conducted by Crowe Horwath asked farmers, rural professionals and others involved in the New Zealand agribusiness for their views on the industry's key influences. Respondents were most concerned about the negative impact of commodity prices, regulation (at a local and central government level), succession issues, climatic conditions and human resources. These issues are generally out of the control of New Zealand farmers, but a focus can be put on building a more resilient farm system, putting in place a strong farm system decision-support process, and using advisors to assist in key decisions. Farmers must have all the necessary information to make informed decisions. For example, for input prices and output prices, this means having reliable data like farm records and off-farm information, agricultural statistics and publications. There are some steps farmers can take to reduce the chances of a bad outcome: ? identify possible sources of risk ? realise possible outcomes ? decide on alternative strategies available ? assess the consequences of each possible outcome ? evaluate the trade-off between the cost of the risk and the gains that can be made. Some farmers are willing to accept more risk than others (some are more risk adverse), so the process can be subjective based on personal feelings as well as the information presented. It is best to focus on those things that farmers can influence and having all information to hand in making key choices. Having new technology and farm management systems is something farmers can influence. Reviewing, managing and improving systems enables farmers to have a sense of control in a current market where there is lots of uncertainty. Reacting to unfavourable events after they occur is not good risk management. ?If you need help on improving your systems to aid in decision making, contact the Crowe Horwath team on 858 5540. ##Story Name## ttdairy Two Central Hawke's Bay dairy farm workers are finalists in this year's New Zealand Dairy Awards for the Hawke's Bay/Wairarapa region. More than 450 people entered the national awards that, as well as recognising dairy managers and dairy trainees also recognise the Share Farmer of the Year. All regional winners will compete for the New Zealand titles, which will be announced in May. ##Story Name## ttshearing Piopio shearing contractor Mark Barrowcliffe is proactive about keeping the members of his shearing gang in good shape, and is enlisting the support of Hawke's Bay-based company, Movement Works to cope with the physical demands of the job. Movement Works is run by Laura Hancock, a specialist in increasing and maintaining movement capacity and physical function. She says Barrowcliffe is leading the way with his use of expertise in areas such as physiotherapy and shearing manufacturing to upskill his staff and push the idea of prevention rather than cure. "I have been working with Barrowcliffe's gang, treating them in the evenings after work. "As well as treatment sessions I also work on giving them each a more comprehensive understanding of their own bodies and the biomechanical demands of their job and how to ward off and deal with the detrimental effects that accompany the physically challenging nature of this rural industry." Although she runs other workshops, the one Barrowcliffe is making use of is specific to the shearing industry, Laura says. "It is designed specifically to help shearers, crutchers, rousies and pressers. "They are taught to use spiky balls for self-massage, swiss balls for mobilisation and exercises for movement enhancement and maintenance of physical health and mobility. "Attendees can then use these techniques on a daily basis to increase the body's ability to cope with the extremely high physical demands placed upon it within the shearing industry," she says. As well as helping out with day-to-day health maintenance, Laura recently worked as part of the team attempting to break the three-stand, eight-hour strong wool lamb world record. The shearers were Ringa Paewai, Peter-Lee Ratima and Craig (Hack) Fagan, and the attempt was held at Mike Carter's woolshed just outside Piopio, but called off at lunch time as the required tally was unavailable. Laura says she uses an in-depth understanding of the biomechanical movements required of the body during shearing. "I look for dysfunctional movement patterns and restricted range of motion. I spent a couple of days before the attempt watching the boys shear and analysing their movement and technique, and treating them accordingly. "I worked with a combined approach of sports massage, strapping and kinesio taping to improve their movement, mechanics, function and performance, as well as reduce pain and treat injuries before the attempt, as well as between runs." When running the workshops, Laura says she can do them both on-farm or from her base at Pilates Works in Havelock North. Workshops are available to be run on behalf of any contractor for their staff at any required location, and as well days can be booked for treating employees. ##Story Name## ttletter1 We want to acknowledge the community's frustration at the length of time it is taking to finalise the Ruataniwha Water Storage Scheme. For class times in Dannevirke or Waipukurau, or for any further inquiries contact Dianne at email d.willis@clear.net.nz, or phone 0274 760 074. ##Story Name## 15nigel The barbecued sausages and cupcakes were on Waipukurau's Nigel Hall last week, when he celebrated 40 years working for the New Zealand Post. In 2008 he also received a CHB Promotions award, recognising him as a CHB ambassador, selling CHB to the world with his positive attitude. ##Story Name## 15scouts A Waipukurau Scout leaders initiative is seeing greater co-operation between the scout group and the CHB branch of Forest and Bird. In Otane, about 12 children and 20 adults enjoyed some old fashioned fun and games at the Children's Day celebration organised by Pleroma Social Services. Christine Renata of CHBDC and Safer CHB spoke to the crowd giving feedback gathered from the Street by Street barbecue survey held late last year. ##Story Name## 15reserve Waipawa resident Charlie Hutchison says that far from having his fears allayed about work being carried out on High Street Reserve to tidy up dangerous trees, he's more concerned than ever. Over the last two weeks two independent geo-technical engineers have come and looked at the large track that's been cut through the reserve to allow machinery in to cut and shred the trees. "After discussions with them I'm now concerned that it's not only the public land that's at risk of slipping, it could affect houses on private land on top of the hill as well - we are in deep doo doo," says Charlie. He again questioned why such a wide track had to be cut through the hill, and refuted claims by council utilities manager Brett Way that the track had not been made bigger, rather only had the surface scraped off. "For 20 years that was an access track that was only three quarters of a metre wide. If you are going to scrape it, why use a 30 tonne digger and make it three metres wide?" In fact, he added, why could the trees not have been removed like they had been in the past, without the need for a track and the damage caused to the site. The presence of bentonite soil on the hill was likely to exacerbate the problem, and Charlie was still very concerned that as it stood the situation was serious "and we haven't even had any major rain yet". As of last week he was considering requesting an independent public inquiry into the processes that led to the track being cut in the first place. He also suggested there be a moratorium on cutting any trees in the reserve, except for ones that posed a danger to public safety, for the next 10 years. Council chief executive John Freeman said independent engineers had been brought in to assess the information from a geo-tech point of view, and would give their qualified report within a fortnight. He acknowledged that local knowledge of the area was very useful in cases like this, but to ensure the best use of ratepayer money, a professional opinion was needed before any action taken. ##Story Name## 15briefs There's been a lot of interest in the fate of Lake Hatuma since Cyril Parker raised the issue of its degradation and called for it to be restored to its former glory. The meeting is open to the public and will be held on Wednesday, March 16 at 7pm at the War Memorial Hall in Waipukurau. ##Story Name## 15debbie I'm frequently asked about the 5-4 split in our council voting. Of late the topic appears to have gained some traction with the ludicrous suggestion being we five, myself included, vote irresponsibly for everything to do with Ruataniwha. I'm only a phone call away. 027 405 2882 or 858 7265. ##Story Name## 15building Morrison Low will continue with its audit of the CHB District Council's building department, despite concerns about the consultancy firm's independence raised by councillor Andrew Watts at this month's finance committee meeting. At the end of last year, the council received 50 replies to a letter sent by CHB Mayor Peter Butler to about 60 tradespeople asking for feedback about their dealings with the department. Forty of those were critical, and 10 complimentary. Last week Mr Butler said about 30 letter writers had agreed to participate in the audit, which was hoped to be completed by the end of March or early April. Council chief executive John Freeman said the audit would cover such matters as consent processing and procedures, inspections and whether there were enough people in the right roles, the department's customer focus and a benchmark comparison between the CHB department and those in Hastings, Napier and Tararua. CHB Building Consent Authority (BCA) staff would be interviewed, as well as councillors, and the people who had written letters who were willing to participate. Once this was completed a draft report would be presented to the council's sub-committee considering the issue, and then a presentation would be made to the full council, he said. It had not been decided whether sub-committee meetings would be public, he said. "That will depend on what they are talking about, and if they are talking to a particular builder or staff member." As reported last week Mr Watts said he had concerns about the use of the company Morrison Low as, among other things, it had done past work and is currently contracted to the council on other asset management matters. ##Story Name## 15fire A Waipawa family was lucky to come through relatively unscathed after a house fire that almost completely destroyed their Shanley Street home on Friday, March 4. On Tuesday last week, occupant Thomas Junior Houkamau's arms were still bandaged from burns received trying to put the fire out, after spotting flames at about 9pm in a room being used for storage and a sleepout. A smoke alarm that had been recently installed through the Safer Homes CHB project also did its job to alert Thomas who was sitting outside at the back after dinner when he saw light coming from the room at the front of the house. "I took a closer look and opened the door to see the top mattress on a bunk was burning. I started trying to put it out with my hands and then I saw a towel and was throwing that at it. "I heard glass popping and breaking in the other rooms - the heat was wicked, and once the windows went it really started roaring." Meanwhile the rest of the family, his partner Lisa Clair and their four children, had made their way across the road and the fire service arrived shortly afterwards. Waipawa brigade senior fire fighter Alison Ludlow said two crews each from Waipawa, Otane, and Waipukurau, as well as a command vehicle from Hastings, attended and took about two hours to completely extinguish the blaze. "We had six teams in BAs (breathing apparatus) going in and coming out in 30-minute shifts." Thomas said he was amazed at how quickly the fire spread, taking only about three minutes to get into the ceiling and engulf the next door kitchen area. Just over half of the interior of the house ended up being burnt out, with the remaining area seriously smoke damaged and the building now unliveable. It was thought the fire started from an overloaded multi-board in the storage room. Waipawa chief fire officer Brian Edwards said the Safer Homes CHB project, that aims to have smoke alarms installed in every house in CHB, was paying off with this the third fire in a house where smoke detectors put in by the fire service had helped save lives. He praised the family for getting out of the house and Thomas for backing off when he saw it was too big to deal with. It was also a timely reminder to check that smoke alarms were working, and with winter approaching to check fire boxes and get chimneys cleaned. "It also shows the importance of not overloading multi-boards and if they are getting old and you have doubts get them replaced with a good quality product with a circuit breaker." He also said it was a reminder to make sure families had an evacuation plan in the event of fire, with a designated safe place outside the house to head to. Thomas and Lisa said the community had been very supportive and they had been flooded with replacement household items, and offered accommodation around the corner. "We want to thank everyone for their overwhelming generosity with donations and support - we have been very spoilt," they said. ##Story Name## 15contacts Contact the CHB Mail 76 Ruataniwha St, Waipukurau 4200 Phone: 858 8166 Reporter: Nicki Harper Display advertising: Judi Ellingham, Rebecca Patterson, advertising@chbmail.co.nz Classified: classifieds@chbmail.co.nz Editorial: editorial@chbmail.co.nz Photos: To order photos, go to newspix.co.nz CHB Mail is published by Hawke's Bay Newspapers ##Story Name## 15letters Flushing flows As I understand it, RWSS water is to be used to create flushing flows for the Waipawa and Tukituki rivers. This is to move periphyton , slime and algae growth down the river and out to sea. Poor water quality promotes growth of these undesirables. Judy Mathews A vote for the river The Ruataniwha Water Storage Scheme (RWSS) has been a body of work that has occupied discussions around the region for some years now. More thumbs page 16. ##Story Name## 15meeting About 200 people turned up to the CHB Municipal Theatre on Thursday night last week to hear what was pitched as a chance to "have your say and be heard" about the Ruataniwha Water Storage Scheme. The meeting was the second of four that Hawke's Bay regional councillors Rex Graham, Rick Barker, Peter Beaven and Tom Belford are holding around the region to air their concerns about the dam. In Waipawa, their criticism was targeted at what they claimed were dubious predictions for economic growth in CHB, the cost of water for CHB farmers versus potential returns, nutrient management measures for the health of the rivers, and the lack of consultation on spending $43m on environmental flows. "This dam is not the vision of CHB farmers - it's not farmer conceived or driven and it's not farmer-owned like South Island dams," Mr Graham said. "The investors own this dam and sell the water to get a commercial return - the economics don't stack up for anyone." Mr Belford said that consultants' reports on the economic benefits of the scheme were each built on ones before, accepting the previous assumptions without challenge. Those reports were predicated on the price of water being 20c per cubic metre, but last week the figure presented by HBRIC had risen to 27c per cubic metre, he said. "The latest report going to CHB farmers this week projects the same land use as models of three to four years ago, but the water is 38 per cent more expensive now. "These reports also said that for farmers to make a return from buying dam water they would need to be in the top 20 per cent of farmers using best practice for optimum productivity. "If you only have average productivity, it's very risky - farmers who are not willing or able to be in the top 20 per cent will either need to decline the water, sell their farm or transfer the management to other people." All the councillors were critical of the lack of consultation around the council approving a "provisional decision" on entering the region into a 35-year water user agreement, subject to the scheme proceeding, at a cost of $43 million to ratepayers. Mr Barker said the money could be better spent on other issues in CHB such as dealing with the build up of shingle in the Tukituki River. Audience members were keen to ask questions. BEL Group chief executive Justine Kidd asked the councillors what vision they had for economic development in the region without the dam? Mr Graham responded that water storage was a big factor but that it could be on-farm rather than a big community scheme. Waipukurau dentist John Jukes got hearty applause when he said that the ecological problems around intensified farming should be solved first, before talking about the dam. Former CHB mayor and Hawke's Bay regional councillor Tim Gilbertson said the councillors were giving a slanted view full of half-truths. He objected to claims that only 150 farmers would benefit from the dam, saying it was a long-term plan that would deliver returns over time. "There was no jumping up and down about spending $50 million on new tug boat for Napier Port, and this investment will be returning on the $80 million for the next 70 to 80 years." At the end of the meeting HBRC chairman Fenton Wilson said from his perspective there had been no fatal flaw in the process so far and confirmed the council would be consulting with the public before spending the $43 million on environmental flows. ##Story Name## Dbrotherhood Brotherhood in Death by JD Robb, Hachette, $34.99 JD Robb, aka Nora Roberts, certainly doesn't need any introduction, or any lessons in how to write a gripping thriller. Just another day at the office for JD Robb, and another satisfying read. Tony Nielsen ##Story Name## Dsheep and goats The trouble with Sheep & Goats by Joanna Cannon, Imprint: Borough Press, $34.99 This novel reminds me of a film you might see at a film festival, slow to start with, but becoming more and more engrossing as it moves on and one that stays with you for quite a time afterwards. A quiet slow and thoroughly satisfying read.Margaret Reilly ##Story Name## Dfalling detective The Falling Detective by Christoffer Carlsson, Scribe Publications, $33 The background, and indeed the foreground, of this political thriller is race relations in contemporary Sweden - the often violent clashes between extreme right-wing groups which oppose all immigration, especially from the Middle East, and the left-wing opposition groups which want to welcome and integrate these people into society. It's not surprising her books are best-sellers. An easy read. Rosie Sanderson ##Story Name## Dseuss Peter Shand delves into the newly discovered Dr Seuss stories published after the author's death. What Pet Should I Get? Dr Seuss, Harper Collins, $24.99 Talk about being a kid in a pet shop. Books being resurrected from Theodor Seuss Geisel's long-lost manuscripts would seem - on the title jacket at least - a literal El Dorado, pure gold in terms of reading pleasure for children. However, just like the brother and sister sent into the pet shop by Dad to buy just ONE pet, I feel kind of ambivalent. On one hand, I'm delighted that the late author's wife, Audrey Geisel, and his longtime secretary and friend, Claudia Prescott, discovered the illustrations and text while cleaning out his office in 2013. They fashioned the raw material - a feat in itself involving, for example, painstaking research into the colours Geisel was using at the time - into a finished book that looks and sounds like a bona fide Dr Seuss. But it's NOT The Cat In The Hat, Green Eggs and Ham, or even How The Grinch Stole Christmas, which makes me wonder if there was a good reason why Geisel left the manuscript in his bottom drawer, so to speak. BUT a recurring theme to Dr Seuss books is persistence pays off, and eight pages of 'notes from the publisher' at the end make this book, which became an instant bestseller in America, totally worthwhile. The notes delve into the life of this bestselling author, including his relationships, especially with pets (he chose dogs), and an intriguing backstory to the book and how it was compiled from bits of text taped to uncoloured sketches. Now THAT'S pure gold. Here's an extract that really resonated with me: "Ted Geisel was a perfectionist. He could spend months developing a character; days talking about the placement of a comma. 'I know my stuff looks like it was rattled off in 28 seconds,' he said, 'but every word is a struggle and every sentence is like the pangs of birth'." Horton and the Kwuggerbug (and More Lost Stories) Dr Seuss, Harper Collins, $24.99 Despite what I said in the above review, these Dr Seuss manuscripts must have been genuinely lost because they're THAT good. The genius of Dr Seuss is on the loose, you might say. And each of the four stories hits that Goldilocks zone of bedtime reading: Not too long to stretch your voice and give you a headache after a long day and not too short to have your child begging for another at its conclusion. However, all Kiwi adults concerned about the TPPA should read the title story, Horton and the Kwuggerbug. . The theme is, never enter into a deal with someone unless you are fully aware of ALL the ramifications. Dr Seuss, aka Theodor Seuss Geisel, obviously thought it was an important lesson for kids not to get in over their heads when someone promises them riches. In this case, the coveted Beezlenut tree that the crafty bug persuades Horton to carry him to is over a crocodile-infested lake, up a sheer mountain and across a terrifying crevasse. Horton obliges because a deal (for half the nuts) is a deal and he "must see a deal through". A half-dead Horton realises the full extent of the rort only when the Kwuggerbug hands him his half - the shells of the nuts. Brilliant, Dr Seuss. ##Story Name## 15FrenchFilm A middle-aged Kiwi called Lynn Paterson is circumnavigating New Zealand by kayak in an attempt to be the first female to do so, and to raise funds for the Mental Health Foundation of New Zealand. There is also a LED light headlamp from Action Outdoors Napier, a Helmut Hirler B/W Aotearoa calendar from Artmosphere Gallery, a bouquet inspired by the colours of the sea from The Flower Barrow and two one-hour hire sessions of kayak, paddle and life jacket from Pandora Kayaks, as well as three double passes for Cinema Gold in Havelock North to be won. Tickets for the raffle, to be drawn following the screening, will be available on the night and there will be several spot prizes, including bags of muesli from Peggy Daring, products from Te Mata Figs and a gateau from Picnic/FGSmith/Albion Canteen. ##Story Name## 15kleinpaste If well-known nature champion Ruud Kleinpaste (aka The Bugman) was responsible for education, Hawke's Bay's natural environment would be our classroom. Ruud Kleinpaste is the ambassador for the Cape to City ecological restoration project. He is leading the education part of the programme with Department of Conservation's education programme coordinator Robyn McCool, with additional support from a range of partners including the Hawke's Bay Regional Council. Cape to City aims to 'teach the teachers' and inspire, encourage and equip them to "reconnect students with nature". Last year three schools participated in Cape to City programmes and the future plan is to involve six schools each year, in either student or teacher programmes. Robyn said the positive response and feedback from schools involved has helped confirm that the programme is worth expanding into other schools. Ruud says the course content has been developed in ways that encourages creative hands-on education using the environment as a context for learning across the curriculum. He adds that most of the school curriculum can be taught in a nature context. "It's easy to get inspired by nature. When we are teaching the teachers, we just take them outside and walk around and as they start to observe the environment the questions start coming and they form their learning and content from there. There are so many teachable moments outside." "Nature is one of the best learning environments we have. It's cheap, as there's no need for a physical classroom and all the materials are free, such as spiders and birds. "For example we did a challenge around silk. We asked children to come up with how many creatures produce silk and to write down all the things that we can do with silk. It's pretty uplifting when you get back a sheet full of observations and ideas. "We can cover off numeracy, literacy, science, social studies among others using nature as the education source from year one onward. Art is another obvious topic." Ruud said. Ruud and Cape to City hope to see the programme adopted by all schools within the Cape to City catchment area as well as schools in other regions and cities. Ruud has already started a similar programme with schools in Auckland. Robyn McCool, Cape to City Education programme coordinator is working with EIT Hawke's Bay on an education partnership which will see nature-time teaching principles integrated into the curriculum for year 2 and 3 candidate teachers. "Schools already involved are keeping up their good work and have plans to expand their biodiversity enhancement learning. This is great and will ensure the Cape to City five- year education plan will have an impact on both young lives and the future of our region's biodiversity," said Robin. ? Cape to City is a five-year, $6 million project, a partnership between Hawke's Bay Regional Council, DOC, Cape Sanctuary, Landcare Research, various landowners and businesses as well as iwi and hap. The project has funding from the Aotearoa Foundation. ##Story Name## 15RachelB Kingfish with sauted sweet and sour capsicumsThe meatiness of kingfish teams well with robust flavours and this capsicum saut is a perfect match. Also great with lamb, or by itself with crusty bread for a vegetarian meal. Serves 4 olive oil sea salt and freshly ground black pepper 4 kingfish steaks Sauted sweet and sour capsicums 4 capsicums, thinly sliced - I used a mix of colours 2 red onions, sliced 2 cloves garlic, sliced 2 tbsp brown sugar Half cup red wine vinegar a good handful of shredded fresh basil 1: For the capsicums, heat a large frying pan over a medium-high heat, add enough olive oil to cover base of pan, add capsicums, onions and garlic, cover and cook, tossing, for 10-15 minutes or until vegetables start to soften and colour. 2: Add sugar and cook, tossing, for 2-3 minutes longer. "New Zealand's apple industry is entering an exciting time capturing significant growth, investment and profitability. It's great news for our apple growing regions of Hawke's Bay, Nelson and Central Otago, Gisborne, Waikato, Wairarapa and South Canterbury." ##Story Name## 15podiatrist An urge for a lifestyle change meant a bonus for the Bay when podiatrist and founder of Auckland's largest podiatry group, Alex MacLeod, moved from Auckland - where he has 13 podiatry clinics - to Havelock North. Moving here just over 18 months ago Alex, director and co-owner of Healthy Steps podiatry group, says he chose the region because of the environment and because he liked the choice of schools for his youngest daughter, aged 7. The move coincided with a chance to buy local podiatrist Julie Clarke's practice, while keeping Julie on staff as national clinical manager. Starting with a Taradale clinic, Alex and his Hawke's Bay team - now numbering three podiatrists and four admin staff - have branched out across Hawke's Bay, with a clinic in Havelock North at Peak Fitness with a special focus on sports podiatry, and general clinics in Hastings, Havelock North and a part-time practice at the Tukituki Medical Centre in Waipukurau. While Healthy Steps has a firm skill base across all aspects of podiatry, the Havelock North clinic for example incorporates gait analysis equipment, a particular passion for the team is diabetic foot care. "Healthy Steps has several contracts for diabetic podiatry treatment across Auckland and over the last 10 years we have helped contribute to a really low amputation rate there. We want to get the amputation rate down in Hawke's Bay also," says Alex. Healthy Steps completed an auditing process with the Hawke's Bay DHB and gained the contract for diabetic podiatry from Central Hawke's Bay to Wairoa. A key focus for the team is to prevent damage to diabetic feet, by education and early intervention. "As a podiatrist, you only have to spend a day at the hospital looking at ulcers and feet about to be amputated, to become passionate about helping," Alex says. "You look at the patients and how it affects them - physically and emotionally - and somewhere along the line it could have been prevented. "Diabetes has been referred to as 'the next health tsunami'. People are often unaware of the implications of some of their lifestyle choices. We want to put resources into diabetic education, teach people about the complications and prevent them." Diabetes affects the bloodstream and the nerve supply. This means patients may not feel damage or injury to their feet but it also means once damage has occurred it does not easily heal. "This leads to ulceration, which leads to amputation. Our mission is to reduce the number of below the knee amputations due to diabetes." While diabetes used to be "typically a middle-aged problem" Alex says it is now across all ages, all ethnicities and all populations. Healthy Steps wants all diabetics and their families to be aware of the complications and they want all diabetics to get their feet checked. "The check is free. If we find they have high risk factors, further treatment is free. If they have low risk factors we have an affordable fee structure so they can continue to see us. We want to prevent problems before they happen." Healthy Steps has made the process simple by using just one 0800 number - 0800myfoot (0800 693668) - and they have letter, text and phone call follow-up to make sure patients remeber appointments. They can also make referrals to dieticians, physiotherapists and whanau support. "We'd rather refer at a low level and get people on track than see them in hospital" Alex says. ?If you have foot pain or concerns about your feet - from sports injuries to cracked heels, corns or plantar faciitis - and want to investigate general or diabetic podiatry care, call Healthy Steps on 0800 693668 for an appointment with a clinic near you. ##Story Name## 15eyes One of the most common conditions we see in optometry practice is an inflammatory condition of part of the eyelid called blepharitis. Symptoms include dryness, burning, itching, stickiness, watering, light sensitivity, red eyes, frequent styes and intermittent blurred vision. Many people with blepharitis suffer no discomfort or symptoms at all but, if left unmanaged, it can cause dry-eye symptoms and eyelid inflammation. The most common form of eyelid blepharitis is meibomian gland dysfunction (MGD), also termed posterior blepharitis. The meibomian glands are located in the eyelids and they secrete the oily layer of the tear film that is crucial in preventing rapid evaporation of tears. The oil glands become blocked with thickened secretions, and chronically clogged glands eventually become unable to secrete oil which results in permanent changes in the tear film and dry eyes. Your oil glands have gone on strike. There are other forms of blepharitis - some caused by microscopic mites and their waste materials or one that creates flaking and scaling - including on the eyelids. There are others too. Chronic blepharitis in any form left untreated will cause meibomian gland dysfunction. Although blepharitis is quite common, unfortunately it often goes undiagnosed. Even when diagnosed it is often not treated or is not treated effectively until it has become chronic or severe. Eyelid hygiene is the cornerstone of treatment for most cases of blepharitis and, in most cases, needs to be an ongoing commitment at home. Besides a programme of eyelid hygiene, the severity of the blepharitis and related symptoms may require supplemental treatment with topical and oral medicine, nutritional supplements such as omega-3 fatty acids, and lubricant eye drops. However, for cases of meibomian gland dysfunction optometrists, or ophthalmologists, may also offer in house treatments such as meibomian gland expression and IPL. IPL is a fairly new treatment for meibomian gland dysfunction that uses polychromatic pulsed light to stimulate the meibomian glands in order for them to return to their normal function. For those who suffer dry eye related to meibomian gland dysfunction IPL treatment can give relief that lasts for months. During an eye examination your optometrist can diagnose blepharitis and dry eye, and differentiate between the different forms so that treatment is targeted most appropriately to the cause. ##Story Name## 15abundant You may have heard of Co enzyme Q10 (CoQ10). Over the next month we will discover what it is, how it works and when it can be beneficial to add as supplements. Sometimes CoQ10 should be taken as a separate supplement; sometimes it is best when combined with other compounds. The main role of CoQ10 is in our cell energy engines - our amazing mitochondria. CoQ10 is essential for making the energy our bodies need. It acts a little like both the fuel line and spark plugs in your car. It is used to transport energy within mitochondria and then acts like a spark plug to ignite energy. Ageing, some drugs, especially cholesterol-reducing drugs and several diseases reduce CoQ10 levels, which can have dire consequences for our health. CoQ10 is what chemists call a "redox" agent. This means it can switch between its oxidised state as ubiquinone then change to its reduce state of ubiquinol. It does this by gaining and losing electrons. When it loses electrons it becomes fully oxidised ubiquinone. When it gains electrons it becomes fully reduced ubiquinol. The reality is both work well from supplements and the body freely switches as needed. Historically the best CoQ10 is made by one company, the Kaneka Corporation in Japan who developed the complex process to make nature identical CoQ10. Any product using Kaneka Q10R will be outstanding though generally be a little more expensive. The most common reason I recommend CoQ10 is to be taken alongside statin medications to protect against the muscle weakness and pain, low energy and depressed mood associated with these drugs. Give me a call or email if you need more information. ##Story Name## 15BrainHealth Celebrated neuroplasticity and healthy brain specialist Dr Helena Popovic will visit Napier on Sunday, April 3, for a once-only speaking appearance at 2pm at the Municipal Theatre. Dr Popovic is an internationally acclaimed specialist on brain health and how people can improve their brains at any age. The Alzheimers Societies of Napier and Hastings are promoting the benefits of healthy brains by bringing Dr Popovic to speak to an expected large audience. Alzheimers Napier and Alzheimers Hastings Managers, Tania Roebuck and Cheryl Robinson say the session, Boost your Brain and Defy Dementia, is an inspirational seminar about how people can take positive action and achieve extraordinary results. The Alzheimer societies say this is a seminar that anybody who is interested in the long-term health of their brain and general well-being as they age should go to. Dr Popovic has proved that at any age we can sharpen thinking, improve concentration and memory and expand creativity. The emerging field of neuroplasticity, or how the brain can change its own structure and function according to what we do, how we behave and we think, is at the heart of Dr Popovic's work. Dr Popovic knows that helping people in these ways reduces the risk of developing depression, anxiety disorders and Alzheimers disease. Education to help look after your brain is relevant to any age and it is part of the Alzheimers Societies' work to promote inclusion of brain health in an overall healthy lifestyle. Dr Popovic is a popular business speaker in Australia and does a lot of work helping people improve their employees' performance. ? Tickets for Dr Popovic's seminar are available at the Municipal Theatre, Napier or online through Ticketek. ##Story Name## 15Health2 Are you a woman in her 40s, 50s or 60s? The physical and psychological changes that occur during these midlife years can cause emotional stress that may lead to unwanted weight gain. Do you feel overweight, sluggish and when you look in the mirror - if you dare - not like what you see? Our midlife years can be challenging for us at the best of times. We may have financial burdens, face retirement, an empty nest, a parent's illness or death, career moves and residential changes. All this plus the side effects of menopause, mood swings, hot flushes, slowed metabolism and the redistribution of body weight. This time of our lives can be the most frustrating for us in terms of maintaining an ideal body weight. So what's a girl to do? During long-term stress your body sets in motion a chain of events that reads like a whodunnit. Your hormones play tag with each other, releasing cortisol into your body. This prepares your body for an instant state of readiness in the classic "fight or flight" response. You know these feelings - nervous, jittery, tense, tearful, on edge - and when you feel this way other hormones direct us to find food, or alcohol, for comfort. Food like chocolate becomes our saviour. We eat and we feel better ... for a while. Once the stressful situation has passed our hormones settle down and we're left with feeling "normal" for a while ... until another stressful situation arises and has us reaching for that block of chocolate or that glass of alcohol. Strategies for dealing with stress should include exercise as part of a balanced approach. Exercise is a powerful tamer of emotional stress and menopausal symptoms. Fortunately, in Hawke's Bay we have access to beautiful walking spaces, a variety of gyms, sports clubs and activity options. Eating healthy meals and staying away from sugary and processed food is hard to do at the best of times and when you are stressed these are the very foods you turn to for comfort. Keep a food diary and see if you can identify your "emotional eating" times. Then resolve to change them one by one by, say, replacing the chocolate with a piece of fruit - not as exciting, however the goal is to look great and feel better and taking one step at a time is how to do it. Midlife emotions can be a challenge, so take control and navigate your way to a healthier, happier you. ##Story Name## 15DianeStride Following the success of last year's event, the Women's Health Series is back this year. All the proceeds of the evening will again be going to Child Cancer Hawke's Bay, so invite a friend and go along for a fun and informative evening. "We had such a great turnout last year, with more than 200 women coming out to listen to our experts. It really highlighted the need for this type of information to be available," says Diane Stride, a dietitian based in Havelock North at the Village Health Centre and organiser of the event. This time Diane will be speaking about nutrition. "My topic is called Nutrition versus Intuition: The art of eating. This is a topic that I am really passionate about, as it plays such an important role in what we eat. "We are living in a time with 'information overload' about nutrition, and people are getting really confused. I want to simplify things by taking it back to basics for people, so that they understand how all the components of diet fit together. "The way people view food has changed and knowledge and values around food is different from how it was years ago. These factors are often subconscious or forgotten, and affect us to a greater or lesser extent. The talk will be a mixture of scientific facts, research information and practical challenges and tips to make it more relevant," Diane says. Dr Derek Goodisson, a surgeon in Hawke's Bay specialising in head and neck surgery, including facial reconstruction and head and neck cancer, will be speaking about early detection of skin cancer. He has a special interest in skin cancer, and due to its high incidence in Hawke's Bay he wants to get the message out. His session will be interactive and will cover a range of topics including screening for skin cancer, prevention, where and when people should go for assistance and what some of the treatments are. "This is a fantastic opportunity to hear first hand from a leading expert in the field," says Diane. The evening's panel of experts includes gynaecologist Dr Keith Harrison and endocrinologist Dr Ole Schmiedel and the format will be slightly different. People can submit questions anonymously to diane@dietitianconsultant.co.nz Questions chosen will be around topics that are of interest to a wide range of people, for example adrenal fatigue - how is it diagnosed? Cortisol - how do I know if my levels are low and how does that affect me? Pre-diabetes, hormone replacement therapy, endometriosis and more. The Women's Health Series is suitable for women of all ages, but particularly women aged 16 years and up, as many of the issues discussed are not age-related. Even though it is called the Women's Health Series, men can come too, says Diane, as they may find some of the topics interesting. Last year the tickets sold out. All the specialists are giving their time for free, with all proceeds from the evening going to the Child Cancer Foundation. "We are delighted to be involved with Diane and her colleagues once again, which will not only benefit children with cancer and their families, but will be great interest to many Hawke's Bay residents," Vicky Rope, business development manager for the Child Cancer Foundation in Hawke's Bay says. Women's Health Series - at the Village Baptist Church Auditorium, 147 Te Aute Road, Havelock North. Thursday March 17 at 7pm (doors open at 6.45pm). Tickets are $25 and available at the i-Sites in Havelock North, Napier and Hastings and at Monique Therese Jeweller in Havelock North. Online sales are also available via email to diane@dietitianconsultant.co.nz. There will be gift bags and spot prizes on the night. A unique piece of jewellery has been designed and donated by Monique Therese Jewellers, and will be raffled on the night. ##Story Name## 15concert The Himmerland Concert with special guest Nuala Kennedy is a chance for people with an interest in World and Celtic music to attend a concert right here in Havelock North. Himmerland with Nuala Kennedy are fresh from sold out performances at Glasgow's iconic Celtic Connections Arts and Music Festival, and they will be touring New Zealand for three weeks in March and April as guests at the CubaDupa Street Festival in Wellington, Tauranga Jazz Festival and the Canterbury Folk Festival. They are playing at clubs and venues all over New Zealand. They will perform at the Havelock North Function Centre on March 24. Himmerland is a group of musicians with different life stories and traditions. They come from Denmark, Poland, Ireland and Ghana. Their original music is infused with different traditions from the Faroes, Sweden, Bulgaria, Italy, Belgium, Scotland, Ukraine, South America and Ireland. Nuala Kennedy is a buoyant Irish singer and flute player with a beautiful voice and adventurous instrumentation. Nuala's singing and flute playing springs from the traditional music of Ireland and Scotland and from the depths of her imagination. Eskil Romme, soprano saxophone has lived in Himmerlands in Northern Jutland most of his life. During the 30 years Eskil has been playing he has mixed traditional Danish music with jazz and other related genres which includes a close association with some of the world's best Celtic musicians. Sigurd Hockings on guitar is one of the most skilful and versatile folk guitarists in Denmark. Inspiration for his individual and accomplished playing style has come from the Scandinavian and Celtic music traditions. Ayi Solomon on percussion and vocals is from Ghana but has lived in Copenhagen for more than 30 years. Solomon enjoys great respect wherever he has played both in Denmark and internationally. He has performed and toured with a wide range of top professional bands. Solomon is a lively and entertaining performer and is able to hold audiences spellbound as he weaves his magic on percussion. ? Himmerland with special guest Nuala Kennedy Where: Havelock North Function Centre, Te Mata Road Havelock North. When: Thursday March 24, 8pm Doors open: 7pm. Bar and snacks available ##Story Name## 15festival1 CK Stead, the current New Zealand Poet Laureate, will be officially honoured at the Poets' Night Out, at the Havelock North Function Centre at 7.30pm on Saturday April 2. Stead has invited award winning poets Gregory O'Brien, Chris Price and Paula Green to share this evening with him as guest readers. National Library spokesman Peter Ireland says this cultural event is an important and popular occasion in Hawke's Bay. "Poets' Night Out is a wonderful chance for Hawkes' Bay to be part of this special occasion honouring the Poet Laureate in Havelock North, the birthplace of the Poet Laureate programme." Stead will receive his hand-carved tokotoko during a special ceremony at Matahiwi marae earlier in the day. Each Laureate receives their own tokotoko - a ceremonial carved walking stick - symbolising their authority and status. The National Library holds the matua, or parent tokotoko, to signify their guardianship of the New Zealand Poet Laureate Award. The tokotoko is a link to the Hawke's Bay origins of the award, and is created by Haumoana artist Jacob Scott. The National Library assumed responsibility for the New Zealand Poet Laureate Award from Te Mata Estate Winery in 2007. Hawke's Bay poet Marty Smith, winner of the Jesse McKay award in the 2014 national book awards, says the evening always has a special kind of magic. "Poetry travels though poets like electricity, and the sequence of readings from CK Stead and his guests is a chance to hear exciting poets shock us sideways into other ways of looking. "Music and poetry are closely linked, and it's our pleasure to support Project Prima Volta by showcasing these talented young singers who represent the future of the arts. This big shout out to the Poet Laureate will be a stunning evening of celebration." ? Tickets: $20, available from Creative Hastings, Hastings Libraries, Napier Libraries and Beattie and Forbes or online at Eventfinder. ##Story Name## 15easterhunt Porse in Hastings is inviting children and parents to an Easter Egg Hunt at Cornwall Park on Thursday March 24. Children are invited to dress up as bunnies, or their favourite character, bring along parents, friends and a picnic (and sunhats and sunscreen) and join in the free activities, including a bouncy castle and facepainting. The Easter egg hunt will be from 10am until 11.30am near the play area at Cornwall Park, Hastings. If you'd like to go along please RSVP by Friday march 18, to 876 6011, extension 3, just so the Easter Bunny knows how many eggs to bring along. ##Story Name## 15exhibition The name William Rush is synonymous with Hawke's Bay heritage architecture. William designed many of the wonderful old buildings around Havelock North, including Iona College. He was also a highly accomplished artist, often described as one of New Zealand's most important early painters, whose watercolours of Hawke's Bay and Taupo depict the history of New Zealand in an illuminating and fascinating manner. His late daughter, Helen Lester, an Iona Old Girl, donated 50 of his works from her private collection to Iona, and over the weekend of March 19 and 20, these will be sold to raise funds for the Iona Heritage Room refurbishment. The works will be on display for the first time, in the award-winning Blyth Performing Arts Centre at Iona - recently judged the best NZ building of 2015 and awarded the New Zealand Architecture Medal. In capturing many of his favourite scenes around New Zealand, Rush has preserved in perpetuity the natural beauty of the historic landscape. These paintings are meticulously and skilfully executed, an outstanding reminder of Hawke's Bay heritage. The public are invited to view the works of William Rush and take the chance to acquire their own slice of New Zealand history. The exhibition runs Saturday March 19 from 10am to 3pm and Sunday March 20 from 1pm to 3pm. All 50 works are available for purchase at a fixed price during the exhibition. ##Story Name## 15gala Originally excavated with help from the students in 1915, the original Hereworth swimming pool will be upgraded with funds to be raised at the school's French fair on Sunday March 20. The pool is believed to be one of the earliest school pools built in Hawke's Bay, although records are sketchy about the exact date it was completed. School historian Railene Mabin says learning how to swim in the early 1900s was vital, due to the large number of drownings at river crossings. "Building a school pool was seen to be ahead of its time in those days, however it was quickly viewed as a very good investment in the boys' health and welfare." Before the school pool was built, the boys swam in the Waikoko Lake, now the Hastings Showgrounds. The school had suffered a tragedy in 1897 when the headmaster William Rainbow drowned while attempting to rescue two students on a school picnic at a local river. Hereworth Parents' Association president, Hugh Ritchie, says maintaining the pool is as important as ever, as many school pools around New Zealand have been decommissioned. "It's great to see the facility being used, particularly by the boarders who are really enjoying the improvements so far." The Hereworth Old Boys' Association, led by president James Nilsson, began work on the pool during the summer holidays, getting it painted and ready to swim in for the start of the school year. "The biggest part of the project was having to grind out nearly 200 linear metres of cracks and seal them, to stop the leaking." Hereworth headmaster Steve Fiet says celebrating the history of the school pool is a vital part of the school's ongoing success. "We would love to hear from anyone who has information on the history of the school swimming pool or any memorabilia, particularly photos, from those early days." The Hereworth French Affair Gala will be held on March 20 with the gates open at 10am. The Hereworth grounds will come alive with all the flavours of a French fair including a wide array of food stalls, fresh produce, Easter treats, French cars, bric-a-brac, pre-loved haute couture, plus good old-fashioned children's entertainment, a cricket machine and pony rides. An art auction featuring works from well-known and emerging artists, along with a number of celebrity lots will start at 12.30pm with auctioneer Simon Tremain in charge of proceedings. Auction organisers say there are some real gems up for grabs, including paintings from Angus Walker and Anna Jepson, and photography from Lee Warren. A percentage of the proceeds from the art auction will be donated to the Limitless Hope Charity. ##Story Name## 15toughKids Last week 2500 students crawled through cargo nets, climbed over cable drums and tested their balance to prove they were Hawke's Bay's toughest kid. Children from Years 3 to 8 competed in a 26-piece obstacle course for the third annual Mitre 10 MEGA Tough Kid at Hawke's Bay Regional Sports Park. The event went off without a hitch, organiser Kerry Meehan said, where students and the hundreds of parents who came to watch had a great time. "It was absolutely brilliant," she said. "It worked well, everyone had fun and there was a good atmosphere." Of the 45 schools which entered, the two toughest schools with the highest percentage of entrants, were Havelock North Primary school and Taradale Intermediate school. With obstacles ranging from tyres, a climbing wall, and cargo nets, the students seemed to have some favourites. "They absolutely loved the water slide, and the fire truck hosing them down," Ms Meehan said. "They got quite muddy and soapy. It was messy business." Ms Meehan said they had a few minor hiccups, such as the inflatables trying to make a break for it in yesterday's high wind, but everything else "went according to plan". Aside from seeing the students' enjoyment, Ms Meehan said a highlight of the day was seeing them all work together. "Kids would fall but they'd pick themselves up again, and their friends would be encouraging them," she said. "The schools really stuck together. They would hold hands and look out for each other ... there was good sportsmanship." She said some of the pieces were "a bit scary", but the kids helped each other get past the obstacles. Another highlight was the estimated $8000 raised for Breath HB from the event. Some of this came from the 3000 sausages brought by Rapid Relief, which were donated and cooked to raise more money

title: RME Rocky Mtn Dealerships earns $11.29-million in 2015
article: Rocky Mountain Dealerships Inc (TSX:RME) Shares Issued 19,384,086 Last Close 3/15/2016 $5.95 Tuesday March 15 2016 - News Release Mr. Garrett Ganden reports ROCKY MOUNTAIN DEALERSHIPS INC. (TSX:RME, OTCQX:RCKXF) ANNOUNCES 2015 FOURTH QUARTER AND YEAR-END RESULTS Rocky Mountain Dealerships Inc. has released its financial results for the quarter and year ended Dec. 31, 2015. Summary of the quarter ended Dec. 31, 2015: - Total revenues decreased by 2.9 per cent to $285.6-million. - Used equipment sales increased by 16.1 per cent to $92.7-million. - Gross profit decreased by 4.9 per cent to $37.5-million (13.1 per cent of sales). - Adjusted diluted earnings per share declined by 21.9 per cent to 25 cents. - Adjusted earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization declined 16.6 per cent to $9.0-million. - Inventory increased by $10.1-million to $499.8-million. Summary of the year ended Dec. 31, 2015: - Total revenues increased by 1.0 per cent to $975.5-million. - Same-store agriculture sales held flat despite softer industry demand. - Used equipment sales increased by 24.4 per cent to $377.5-million. - Gross profit decreased by 2.5 per cent to $142.0-million (14.6 per cent of sales). - Adjusted diluted earnings per share declined by 26.8 per cent to 71 cents. - Adjusted EBITDA declined 18.9 per cent to $28.6-million. - Inventory decreased by $69.8-million to $499.8-million. - Expanded the sales territory through the acquisition of Chabot. - Completed the construction of its new facility in Neepawa, Man. During 2015, Rocky was able to deliver strong gains in several key areas in what was a challenging operating environment. Among other factors, the impact of the U.S. exchange rate on new equipment prices dictated a different approach to equipment purchasing in 2015, bolstering demand for used equipment and product support within the company's agriculture segment. Initiatives undertaken by Rocky in response to these changes focused resources and efforts on these areas of demand, resulting in revenue growth and improved cash flow. The continued demand for lightly used equipment helped drive down inventory levels by $68.9-million during 2015, excluding inventory acquired through business combinations. On the industrials front, the persistence of the depression in oil prices continued to negatively impact economic activity in Alberta. Cost containment initiatives undertaken by Rocky in 2014 and 2015 helped to curtail losses in that regard during the year. "Rocky was able to leverage the market conditions that prevailed in 2015 to further our existing initiatives to reduce inventory and build our product support business," remarked Garrett Ganden, president and chief executive officer of Rocky. "As we continue to grow our installed base of agriculture equipment and customers, we anticipate further demand for our product support business, which posted another strong year in 2015. We were also pleased to see the consistency in our same-store agriculture revenue year over year, despite softer overall equipment demand. "In addition to these operational initiatives, Rocky was able to further grow its footprint in 2015 by acquiring Chabot Implements, a long-standing dealer of Case IH products in Manitoba. This strategic acquisition allowed us to further consolidate our position as a major equipment distributor in the Manitoba region. We were also able to enhance our product and service offering in the area of geomatics and precision farming through our acquisition of NGF Geomatics. As farms get larger and more technologically sophisticated, we feel that Rocky is well positioned to meet their equipment and technology demands. "The cost containment strategies that we enacted during the year offset much of the incremental SG&A [sales, general and administration] associated with our acquisitions. As part of this process, we undertook initiatives to reduce our fixed charges by amalgamating locations in certain regions. We believe that the steps taken in this regard will allow us to uphold the level of service and territory coverage that our customers expect, at a reduced cost. Due to investments we have made in process and efficiency, we were able to both grow our sales territory and shrink our bricks-and-mortar footprint, with little interruption to our core business. "Our industrial segment lost some of the traction that they had gained in 2014, due primarily to the precipitous drop in oil prices, and its effect on the Alberta economy. While Rocky's industrials segment is not reliant on doing business directly with Alberta's oil industry, we still are prone to the indirect effects that this downturn has created. We continue to work on initiatives to further our brand and ultimately achieve profitability despite these challenges." Mr. Ganden concluded his comments by saying: "Our focus continues to be the safe, dependable equipment partner of choice for our agriculture and industrial customers. We continue to lay the groundwork for maintaining and growing customer relationships across our network. To that end, in 2015, we were pleased to open a new, state-of-the-art store in Neepawa, Man., and we are looking forward to the completion of our new, larger store in Yorkton, Sask., in the coming weeks. Through these investments in our facilities and in the communities we operate, we hope to maintain the continued annuity of business that these relationships can create." Annual meeting of shareholders Rocky also announced today that its annual meeting of shareholders (AGM) will take place at 2 p.m. on May 3, 2016, in the showroom of Rocky Mountain Equipment, 260180 Writing Creek Cres., Rocky View county, in Alberta. Materials related to the coming AGM will be sent in mid-April, 2016, to shareholders of record at the close of business on March 29, 2016. Quarterly cash dividend On Feb. 2, 2016, Rocky's board of directors approved a quarterly dividend of 11.5 cents per common share on its outstanding common shares. The common share dividend is payable on March 31, 2016, to shareholders of record at the close of business on Feb. 29, 2016. This dividend is designated by Rocky to be an eligible dividend for the purposes of the Income Tax Act (Canada) and any similar provincial or territorial legislation. An enhanced dividend tax credit applies to eligible dividends paid to Canadian residents. Please consult with your own tax adviser for advice with respect to the income tax consequences to you from Rocky designating its dividends as eligible dividends. Conference call On March 16, 2016, Rocky will discuss its results by live conference call and audio webcast, beginning at 9 a.m. Mountain Time (11 a.m. Eastern Time). Senior management of Rocky will provide remarks on the period, followed by a question-and-answer session with analysts and institutional investors. Those interested in participating in the conference call may do so by calling 1-888-231-8191 (toll-free) or 1-647-427-7450. A live webcast of the conference call will also be accessible through Rocky's website. An archived recording of the conference call will be available until March 30, 2016, by dialling 1-855-859-2056 (toll-free) or 1-416-849-0833, passcode 42558477. This archived recording will also be available on Rocky's website.  We seek Safe Harbor.

title: Federal government investment and more staff needed to grow Canada's unmanned aerial systems industry
article: By Mark Aruja Defence Watch Guest Writer Canada, with its vast geography, low population density, abundance of resources and challenging environment created the conditions to invent bush flying and the related technologies and know-how. Today, aviation in remote locations is a hallmark of Canadian aviation industry around the world. The next big step is to do some of these most challenging tasks with Unmanned Aerial Systems (UAS), where we can once again lead the world in innovation in operating in remote areas. As Canada's national non-profit association representing public and private innovation in unmanned vehicle systems, Unmanned Systems Canada has spearheaded initiatives which have resulted in the dramatic growth of the UAS industry in Canada. However, we are now at an impasse. With modest, but immediate government action, this impasse can and will be bridged with substantive impacts on the economy, and renewed innovation with novel applications of UAS technology. The growth of the Canadian UAS sector in Canada has benefited from our close collaborative efforts over many years of work with Transport Canada. The "UAV Program Design Working Group" co-chaired by Transport Canada and Unmanned Systems Canada is an industry and government stakeholder committee formed in 2010, tasked with developing a suite of proposed regulations enabling routine unmanned aircraft operations (aka "file and fly") in Canada. The regulations development process was divided into four distinct phases as a function of risk: UAS under 25kg., operating within visual line of sight of the pilot; UAS under 25kg., operating beyond visual line of sight of the pilot; UAS between 25 and 150kg., operating beyond visual line of sight; and UAS over 150kg operating beyond visual line of sight. Phase 1 was completed in 2012 and has resulted in a Notice of Proposed Amendment which is expected to become law in 2017. However, these regulations will only address UAS operations within Visual Line of Sight of the operator. Clearly, monitoring the integrity of Canadian pipelines and hydro lines, measuring the bulk value of our forests, environmental monitoring of the Arctic, are but some of the applications where operations must be conducted Beyond Visual Line of Sight (BVLOS). The Phase 2 working group report on recommended changes to Canadian Aviation Regulations to enable BLVOS operations has been completed. It now requires the resources for implementation. Today, UAS operations are authorized by Transport Canada with the issuance of a Special Flight Operations Certificate (SFOC). Whereas virtually no SFOCs were issued when we started working in earnest with Transport Canada, by 2012 that number had grown to 345, then 945 in 2013 and 1,672 in 2014: we expect that the 2015 tally will follow that growth curve. These SFOCs are being achieved by industry and the regulator working to the results of the Phase 1 work, while awaiting formalization in law. What this means is, that the regulatory efforts to date, have already realized the remarkable economic growth which Unmanned Systems Canada had projected! Every day, somewhere in Canada UAS are: o Rapidly providing police with high quality airborne data for accident scene reconstruction, significantly reducing the time for reopening our transportation arteries; o Undertaking monitoring of structures such as industrial flare stacks and cell phone towers, improving safety while lowering costs; o Increasing crop yields while reducing the use of pesticides and herbicides and growing the discipline of precision agriculture; o Used for environmental monitoring ranging from non-intrusive surveillance of bird sanctuaries to industrial facilities in our energy sector; o Used on film sets to improve the quality of their product, while enhancing the competitiveness of our film industry; and o Site planning, project monitoring, aggregate pit measurements and a host of other applications in the construction industry. In addition, at least 20 Canadian academic institutions and companies now offer training programs on UAS systems; there have been major steps taken by the insurance industry to address risk management, and so much more. While our industry has grown exponentially, there has been little or no growth in the critical Government staff required to support this federally regulated economic sector. All of the existing federal government personnel resources assigned to the UAS sector will be occupied for at least the next 18 months on the review and approval of the new regulations noted above. The direct impact is that the draft BVLOS regulatory recommendations and standards resulting from the completion of the second phase of the working group with TC continue to await staff availability for formal staffing and approval within the Department. The recommendations and standards proposed in this phase are critical to the future of our industry and will truly release the economic potential. Some technology development remains to meet the "sense and avoid" capability to fully permit BVLOS operations; however publishing the standards recommended by the working group will provide industry and R&D organizations with the required design objectives. In addition, because BVLOS technology and operations experience is exportable for mining survey, environmental monitoring and a host of other applications, we risk losing a world-leading opportunity. Therefore, we propose that: o The federal government immediately increase the staffing levels of experts at Transport Canada with a mandate to proceed without delay to review, approve and implement the BVLOS guidelines; o That the federal government identify specific funding through Innovation, Science and Economic Development and the National Research Council to enable BVLOS operations by working with and funding Canadian companies to test, and if needed close technology gaps with improved 'sense and avoid' systems; o Financial incentives be created for small aircraft operators and equipment manufacturers to install Automatic Dependent Surveillance - Broadcast (ADS-B) equipment into all aircraft. ADS-B promises to greatly improve aviation safety, and in particular the safe integration of UAS into our airspace as an existing aid in sense and avoid technology; and o Ensure that interdepartmental (e.g. Statistics Canada, Global Affairs, ISED, TC) resources are assigned to a collaborative effort to measure this new economic sector in order to support evidence-based public policy making and investment by the private sector. Policy must also encourage growth in this new economic sector through targeted Industrial Technology Benefits (ITB) requirements on any federal government UAS procurements. Canadian industry has worked diligently and persistently with the federal government to create hundreds of new companies and commercial initiatives and the creation of a Canadian UAS industry in only a few years. However, we risk being rapidly overtaken by our competitors without commensurate support from the federal government. Other jurisdictions, notably the UK, US and European governments and regulatory bodies are investing heavily and working closely with industry to test how technologies can facilitate safe BVLOS operations in preparation for rulemaking. With the timely implementation of our modest recommendations, we can ensure that the economic outcomes of Canadian innovation can continue apace, and, we can keep Canadian companies in a position of world leadership. (Mark Aruja is Chairman of the Board Unmanned Systems Canada)
